is a beach-side village in the municipality of
Itaúnas is located in the northernmost part of the state of
. The town's fame was gained because of

, a type of dance popular in Northeastern Brazil, as well as the type of music which accompanies the dance. Every July, Itaúnas is the host of the National Forró Festival. 

Itaúnas is also famous for its dunes. The old town was literally buried by the dunes in the 1960s. Nowadays, the new town is located on the other side of the Itaúnas River.

The whole area is known for its natural beauty, and Itaúnas is also the best support base for those who want to visit the
. The area of the park is approximately 3,600 hectares (8.90 acres), stretching from the mouth of
, up to the mouth of the
(Doce Stream), on the border of the state of

is part of the Atlantic Forest South-East Reserves, which is an UNESCO World Heritage Site. The park is itself an ecological sanctuary permeated by the Itaúnas River, with 38 km (23.61 mil) of beach and seven different ecosystems: beach, river, swamp, growth of mangroves, sandbank and the Tableland Atlantic Forest.

In the park there is a great variety of species from the Brazilian fauna, many of which endangered, such as sloths, capybaras, broad-snouted alligators, otters, parrots, parakeets, maritacas (South American hog-nosed skunks – Conepatus chilensis amazonicus), and jacupengas (Pernelope supercilliaris). 

On the beaches, sea turtles have been protected thanks to the effort endeavored in the Tamar project
, whose goal is to protect and to do research about those animals.
The climate of the area is hot super-humid. The annual average temperature is around 22ºC (71.6° F), with average highs around 28ºC (82.4 °F), and average lows around 18°C (64.4 °F).

For those who prefer excursions on the ecological trails, IBAMA (Brazilian Institute for the Environment and Natural Renewable Resources)

organizes guided visits for tourists.

Sandboarding on the dunes has been prohibited by IBAMA.

content=On this you go up the Itaúnas River, up to the junction with the Angelim River. It lasts two hours on average.
content=It is inside of the Itaúnas State Park, and it is surrounded by the dunes that buried the old town in the 1960's. There are many stands at the seaside there.
content=It is a wild stream that is cut in its whole extension by brooks of dark waters. Beautiful coral formations can be seen.
content=It has high cliffs – over eight meters (26.25 feet) in height – and corals, brooks, as well as mangrove vegetation.

Itaúnas is the support base to visit the park. The town has good options of lodging and restaurants.
